text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
BUSINESS TIMES
- Quoted companies are poised for a showdown with Nigerian stock exchange over directives that they should fees for participation in the newly installed central clearing system.
- A list of mortgage institutions approved to participate in the national housing fund is soon to be released by the Federal Mortgage Bank.
- Venezuela has shown interest in buying Nigeria's Bonny light crude oil in a deal that would involve swapping it for Venezuela's heavy crude.
- Trading would soon begin on derivatives instruments in a move to broaden the range of activities on the stock market.
DAILY TIMES
- Blow to democracy as President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah of Sierra Leone is overthrown in army coup and flees to Guinea.
- Despite elaborate preparations there have been massive leakage in weekend examinations for admission into Nigerian universities.
- Director general of the federal ministry of health, Julius Makanjuola, the top civil servant in the ministry, has been removed and the next most senior officer ordered to take charge.
- Liquidity in financial system has shot up with payment of 10 billion naira to oil companies by the federal government.
- Oil-producing companies call for the scrapping of the Oil Mineral Producing Areas Development Commission, which is charged with providing amenities in Nigerian swamps where oil is mined.
THE GUARDIAN
- Capital grants for government agencies in this year's budget will not be released until they have given account of how they spent last year's vote, says finance minister Anthony Ani.
- Six private telecommunications operators were at the weekend given mandate to be connected to the national telephone grid.
- The Nigerian Emerging Market Fund, with assets worth $7.5 million, may appoint Nigeria International Bank, a subsidiary of Citibank of New York, its local agent.
- Japanese firm Kenwood Corp and Communications Associates of Nigeria Ltd at the weekend signed a marketing agreement on communications equipment.
THISDAY
- A foreign investor, New York-based International Asset Transactions Limited, says it will invest $5 million in the Nigerian stock market over the next nine months.
- Chevron Corp starts work on second phase of its Escravos gas project in Nigeria just weeks after the plant commenced production.
